message_1:
How many complex two-dimensional tori can be realized as Calabi-Yau varieties?

(Note: A complex two-dimensional torus is a surface that can be obtained by gluing opposite sides of a square in the complex plane, known as a parallelogram lattice.)
message_2:
A Calabi-Yau variety is a complex manifold with a vanishing first Chern class and a trivial canonical bundle, which means it has a Ricci-flat metric. In the case of a complex two-dimensional torus, we are considering a complex one-dimensional torus (also known as an elliptic curve) in each complex dimension, making it a product of two elliptic curves.

For a complex two-dimensional torus to be a Calabi-Yau variety, both of the elliptic curves must have a trivial canonical bundle. The canonical bundle of a product of two varieties is the tensor product of the canonical bundles of the individual varieties. Since the canonical bundle of an elliptic curve is trivial, the canonical bundle of the product of two elliptic curves is also trivial.

Therefore, any complex two-dimensional torus, which is a product of two elliptic curves, can be realized as a Calabi-Yau variety. There are infinitely many complex two-dimensional tori, as the shape of the parallelogram lattice can be continuously deformed, and each deformation corresponds to a different complex structure. So, there are infinitely many complex two-dimensional tori that can be realized as Calabi-Yau varieties.
